facts.text: Probate of the will issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942.

facts.text: During lifetime, testator carried on business of shipping agents.

anchor.surface_text: During his life- time, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents. Clause 13 of the will companytains directio

facts.text: Clause 13 of the will directs executors to carry on the business as a going concern after death, up to 12 months, with powers to contract, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of the will companytains directions about carrying on this business of the testator till its disposal. It directs the executors to carry on the business as a going companycern after his death with power to make fresh companytracts and discharge the existing and future liabilities and all other usual-and necessary powers, unless special circum- stances arose which, in the opinion of the executors, made it expedient to sell the business earlier.

facts.text: Executors to ascertain if nephews willing to purchase within 12 months.

anchor.surface_text: This business was to be carried on for a period number exceeding twelve months during which time the executors were to ascertain whether or number any of his nephews was willing to purchase the said undertaking.

facts.text: Executors directed to have valuation made as soon as possible after death.

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose and generally for sale pur- poses, he directed that the executors shall, as soon as possible, after his death, have a valuation made of the said undertak- ing.

facts.text: Business sold to one of the nephews on the 1st of January, 1943.

facts.text: Appellants contended succession to business took place on 1st January, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended that within the meaning of section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, while the taxing

facts.text: Taxing authorities contended succession on 9th April, 1942, when testator died.

anchor.surface_text: 1943, while the taxing authorities companytended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died. The first question submitted for the High Courts opinion

facts.text: High Court answered first question against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The first question submitted for the High Courts opinion related to this dispute. The second question referred to the High Court for its opinion was in respect of an amount paid by the executors to the widow of the testator.

facts.text: Second question on amount paid to widow answered against appellants by High Court, not contested in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The second question referred to the High Court for its opinion was in respect of an amount paid by the executors to the widow of the testator. That question was answered against the appellants by the High Court. Learned companynsel appearing for the appellants intiated that he did number want to companytest the High Courts decision on the point.

facts.text: Appeal limited to first question only.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore is limited to the first question only.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds succession took place on death of testator, 9th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: the date of such succession must be companysidered to be the death of the testator, which was on the 9th of April, 1942. The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Patanjali Sastri J. agrees appeal should be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: PATANJALI SASTRI J.--I agree that this appealshould be rejected.

issues.text: Whether the succession to the business took place on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died, or on the 1st of January, 1943, when the business was sold, within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contended that within the meaning of section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, while the taxing authorities contended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died. The first question submitted for the High Courts opinion related to this dispute.

issues.text: Whether section 26(2) should be construed as applicable only to cases of succession inter vivos or also to succession on death

anchor.surface_text: The first question which arises on the language of the amended section 26  2 , which speaks of the person succeeded being assessed and of his no being found, is whether the sub-section should be construed as applicable only to cases of succession inter vivos.

issues.answer: applicable also to succession on death

issues.text: What is the meaning to be attributed to the phrase 'in such capacity' in sections 25(4) and 26(2)

anchor.surface_text: The next question is what is the meaning to be attributed to the phrase in such capacity? A Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax. Madras 1 , held that the expression meant in the capacity as owner

issues.answer: capacity of carrying on the business liable to tax, regardless of ownership

Thus there came about a change in the assessee

arguments.claim: Succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, when the business was sold to one of the nephews.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contended that within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, while the taxing authorities contended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y another person within the meaning of the same section 25  4 . The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes th

arguments.court_reasoning: Estate vested in executors on death; they carried on business as assessee under ss.3 & 10, effecting change in assessee and thus succession under s.25(4).

arguments.claim: Executors carried on business only for purpose of winding it up under clause 13 of the will, so no succession on death within meaning of s.25(4).

anchor.surface_text: The assessee contends that on the death of the testator under clause 13 of the will of the deceased, the executors were carrying on the business of the deceased only for the purpose of winding it up, and there was no succession to the business on the death of the deceased within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y another person within the meaning of the same section 25  4 . The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes th

arguments.court_reasoning: Vesting of estate in executors on death and their carrying on business as assessee constitutes succession regardless of purpose under will.

arguments.claim: Clause 13 directs carrying on business only to sell as going concern to nephews or others, so succession only on actual sale.

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that the clause provides for nothing else than a direction to carry on the business with a view either (a) to sell it within a year to one of the nephews, or (b) to sell it to someone else at the end of the year as a going concern.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y another person within the meaning of the same section 25  4 . The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes th

arguments.court_reasoning: Purpose of carrying on irrelevant; succession occurs on vesting and change in assessee.

arguments.claim: Succession to business was on 9th April 1942 when testator died.

anchor.surface_text: while the taxing authorities contended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y another person within the meaning of the same section 25  4 . The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes th

arguments.court_reasoning: Executors vested with estate including business on death and carried it on as assessee.

arguments.claim: On death, estate including business vested in executors who carried on business under ss.3 & 10 as assessee, effecting succession under s.25(4).

anchor.surface_text: because on the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee.

arguments.claim: In case of sale/gift by owner, succession on date of sale/gift; similarly on intestate death, heir succeeds on death date.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that in the event of a sale or gift of the business by the original owner the succession within the meaning of section 25(4) will take place only on the date of such sale or gift... Similarly in the event of his death intestate his heir-at-law will succeed to the business on the date of his death.

arguments.claim: Transfer to trustee under settlement causes succession on settlement date, so vesting in executor by law also constitutes succession.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that if the testator had transferred the business to a trustee... there will be a succession... If in such a case that result follows there appears no reason why when the legal estate is transferred by operation of law to an executor there should not be considered a succession...

arguments.claim: 'In such capacity' in s.25(4) makes distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.

arguments.claim: S.25(4) relief consequential on amendment of s.26(2); same meaning of 'succeeded in such capacity'.

anchor.surface_text: It will thus be seen that the enactment of section 25(4) is consequential on the amendment of section 26(2), and the scope and meaning of the expression succeeded in such capacity by another person in section 26(2) must determine also its scope and meaning in section 25(4).

arguments.claim: S.26(2) applies to succession on death, not only inter vivos, due to s.24B and proviso (c) to s.24(9).

anchor.surface_text: there seems to be no sufficient reason for excluding from the scope of the sub-section cases of succession on death in view of the provision in section 24B. On the other hand, proviso (c) to section 24(9), which refers to a person succeeded in such capacity by another person otherwise than by inheritance, would seem to imply that succession... includes devolution on death.

arguments.claim: 'In such capacity' means capacity of carrying on business liable to tax, not as owner (distinguishing Jupudi Kesava Rao).

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Jupudi Kesava Rao... held that the expression meant in the capacity as owner... While it is undoubtedly true... it cannot... be regarded as an essential element of succession...

arguments.claim: Income-tax Act focuses on person carrying on business (assessee under s.2(2), s.10), not ownership; examples in other sections show liability without proprietary interest.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Act directs its attention primarily to the person who receives the income... The assessee is defined in section 2(2)... Such instances are to be found in section 26(2) proviso, section 18(7), section 23-A(3), section 25-A and section 42(1).

arguments.claim: Executors as association carrying on business post-death are successors under s.25(4), liable under ss.3 & 10.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles to the present case... the testator who was carrying on the business... was succeeded in such capacity by the appellants when the former died on 9th April, 1942... They are thus an association of persons carrying on business... under section 10 read with section 3...

arguments.claim: No succession under s.26(2)/25(4) if no break in continuity of interest (same estate bears tax).

anchor.surface_text: It was objected that the appellants being assessable as the representatives of the testator under section 24-B... there could be no real apportionment such as is contemplated by section 26(2) and, therefore, no succession...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ubtedly true that a transfer of ownership is ordi- narily involved in cases of succession failing within sec- tion 26  2  or section 25 4 , it cannot,

arguments.court_reasoning: Executors succeed as carriers of business liable to tax.

arguments.claim: Relief under s.25(4) due to historical double taxation from 1922 Act change.

anchor.surface_text: The reason for this relief is to be found in the change of the basis of taxation when the Act of 1922 was passed which resulted in the profits of the year 1921-22 being assessed twice over...

holdings.text: The date of succession must be considered to be the death of the testator, which was on the 9th of April, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant. The contention that the business was to be carried on by the executors as such, as a going concern or that it was being carried on for the bene- fit or loss of the testators estate is not relevant for the present discussion. The only relevant question under sec- tion 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person. This is a provision to give relief and the scope of the relief must be governed by the words used in the Act. In our opinion the answer to this question, on the facts of the present case, must be in the affirmative and the. date of such succession must be considered to be the death of the testator, which was on the 9th of April, 1942.

holdings.reasoning_summary: On testator's death, estate vested in executors who carried on business as assessee under ss.3 & 10, effecting change in assessee and succession under s.25(4), irrespective of will's purpose.

holdings.text: On the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee. Thus there came about a change in the assessee and therefore a succession in such capacity took place within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: cannot be accepted because on the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee. Thus there came about a change in the assessee and therefore a succession in such capacity took place within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vesting of legal estate in executors by operation of law and their continuation of business as liable assessee constitutes succession.

holdings.text: The words 'in such capacity' in that clause further make the position clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: section 25(4). The words in such capacity in that clause further make the position clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant. The contention that the business was to be carried on by the executors as such, as a going concern or that it was being carried on for the bene- fit or loss of the testators estate is not relevant for the present discussion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'in such capacity' focuses on liability as carrier of business, not ownership type.

holdings.text: The enactment of section 25(4) is consequential on the amendment of section 26(2), and the scope and meaning of the expression 'succeeded in such capacity by another person' in section 26(2) must determine also its scope and meaning in section 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: the relief was extended, by enacting section 25(4), to cases of succession occurring after the commencement of that Act, with the same object as in the case of discontinuance, namely, to redress the hardship of the business having been Charged twice over on the income of 1921-22. In other words, the predecessor is given the same relief as if he had discontinued the business on the date of succession. It will thus be seen that the enactment of section 25(4) is consequential on the amendment of section 26(2), and the scope and meaning of the expression succeeded in such capacity by another person in section 26(2) must determine also its scope and meaning in section 25(4).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction links meanings across sections for consistent relief purpose.

holdings.text: There seems to be no sufficient reason for excluding from the scope of the sub-section cases of succession on death in view of the provision in section 24B. On the other hand, proviso (c) to section 24(9), which refers to a person succeeded in such capacity by another person otherwise than by inheritance, would seem to imply that succession... includes devolution on death.

anchor.surface_text: ed being assessed and of his not being found, is whether the sub-section should be construed as applicable only to cases of succession inter vivos. Whatever force there may have been in the suggestion that the sub-section could not have contemplated cases of testamentary or intestate succession if there was no provision for the assessment of profits earned by a deceased person in the hands his representatives, there seems to be no sufficient reason for excluding from the scope of the sub-section cases of succession on death in view of the provision in section 24B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions like s.24B and proviso to s.24(9) indicate s.26(2) covers succession on death, not limited to inter vivos.

holdings.text: The words 'in such capacity' in sections 25(4) and 26(2) mean nothing more than the capacity of a person who carries on the business as the predecessor was carrying it on that is, with a liability to be taxed on its profits and gains.

anchor.surface_text: The words in such capacity in sections 25(4) and 26(2) mean nothing more than the capacity of a person who carries on the business as the predecessor was carrying it on that is, with a liability to be taxed on its profits and gains.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act focuses on person carrying business and liable to tax (assessee), not ownership; supported by definitions and other sections.

holdings.text: Applying these principles to the present case... the testator who was carrying on the business... was succeeded in such capacity by the appellants when the former died on 9th April, 1942... They are thus an association of persons carrying on business... under section 10 read with section 3.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles to the present case, I am clearly of opinion that the testator who was carrying on the business in question was succeeded in such capacity by the appellants when the former died on 9th April, 1942, and his estate vested in them. As already stated, the testator expressly authorised the appellants to carry on the business as a going concern for one year after his death and gave them power to enter into fresh contracts and to discharge liabilities past and future.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executors as association carrying on business post-death succeed as liable assessee under ss.3 & 10.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. P.E. Poison
precedents.cited_proposition: change of the basis of taxation when the Act of 1922 was passed which resulted in the profits of the year 1921-22 being assessed twice over

precedents.citation: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax. Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax. Madras 1 , held that the expression meant in the capacity as owner , so that the person who succeeds another must, by such succession, become the owner of the business which his predecessor was carrying on

precedents.case_name: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression 'in such capacity' meant 'in the capacity as owner'; sole surviving member of a Hindu undivided family did not succeed to the business of the family within the meaning of section 26(2)
precedents.cited_holding: the sole surviving member of a Hindu undivided family did not succeed to the business within the meaning of section 26(2) as he was previously a part-owner

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Lord Cave in Williams v. Singer Others 1  the fact is that, if the Income-tax Acts are examined, it will be found that the person charged with tax is neither the trustee nor the beneficiary as such, but the person in actual receipt and control of the income, which it is sought to reach.

precedents.cited_proposition: the person charged with tax is neither the trustee nor the beneficiary as such, but the person in actual receipt and control of the income
precedents.cited_holding: if the Income-tax Acts are examined, it will be found that the person charged with tax is neither the trustee nor the beneficiary as such, but the person in actual receipt and control of the income, which it is sought to reach

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; succession to the business by executors occurred on testator's death on 9th April 1942, entitling exemption only up to that date under section 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: clear. It makes the distinction of legal and beneficial ownership irrelevant. The contention that the business was to be carried on by the executors as such, as a going concern or that it was being carried on for the bene- fit or loss of the testators estate is not relevant for the present discussion. The only relevant question under sec- tion 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person. This is a provision to give relief and the scope of the relief must be governed by the words used in the Act. In our opinion the answer to this question, on the facts of the present case, must be in the affirmative and the. date of such succession must be considered to be the death of the testator, which was on the 9th of April, 1942.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: cannot be accepted because on the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee. Thus there came about a change in the assessee and therefore a succession in such capacity took place within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Income-tax Act.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: ed being assessed and of his not being found, is whether the sub-section should be construed as applicable only to cases of succession inter vivos. Whatever force there may have been in the suggestion that the sub-section could not have contemplated cases of testamentary or intestate succession if there was no provision for the assessment of profits earned by a deceased person in the hands his representatives, there seems to be no sufficient reason for excluding from the scope of the sub-section cases of succession on death in view of the provision in section 24B.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 explicitly interprets the meaning of 'in such capacity' in sections 25(4) and 26(2) as the capacity of carrying on the business like the predecessor.

anchor.surface_text: The words in such capacity in sections 25(4) and 26(2) mean nothing more than the capacity of a person who carries on the business as the predecessor was carrying it on that is, with a liability to be taxed on its profits and gains.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles to the present case, I am clearly of opinion that the testator who was carrying on the business in question was succeeded in such capacity by the appellants when the former died on 9th April, 1942, and his estate vested in them. As already stated, the testator expressly authorised the appellants to carry on the business as a going concern for one year after his death and gave them power to enter into fresh contracts and to discharge liabilities past and future.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
